## Facets audit: what’s still missing (candidate additions)
- Human factors & handler psychology (consistency, burnout, training plans for real schedules)
- Dog-human public interaction skills (scripts, de-escalation, access challenges)
- Multi-dog households (management, jealousy/resource issues)
- Kids + dogs safety and training
- Breadth of care (grooming, nails, ears, dental, parasite prevention)
- Ethics and welfare foundations (rest, autonomy, consent behaviors, humane endpoints)
- Internationalization (jurisdiction partitions)

claims.text: This task will be completed by collecting and extracting authoritative sources via Deep Search.

title: Cue Devices (beep/vibrate/flash) Policy
text: ODA treats e-collar hardware strictly as cue devices for beep, vibration, and flash. Shock/stimulation is excluded. Signals must be conditioned with reinforcement; stop and refer if distress or escalation appears.

claims.text: Cue-only signals can be conditioned as prompts/markers when paired with reinforcement; they can also become aversive if introduced poorly, so boundaries are required.

title: Hazards by Category (Evergreen Structure)
text: Facilities hazards are organized by universal categories (cold, heat, wildlife, water, surfaces, noise, air quality/allergens, urban/crowds, travel/transport) to stay evergreen. Location notes belong in tags, not folder names.

claims.text: Category-based hazard organization scales across geographies and reduces taxonomy churn.

title: Housing access (FHA/HUD assistance animals)
text: Housing accommodation for assistance animals should be handled as a documented checklist: receive and log the request, confirm disability-related need when not obvious, and grant the accommodation unless undue burden/fundamental alteration or direct threat can be shown. Avoid invented requirements like registration/certification and avoid pet fees/deposits. Build templates (intake form, what-can-they-ask one-pager, escalation script) so handlers can keep stable housing and providers can stay compliant.

claims.text: Assistance animals are accommodated under FHA/HUD guidance; denial requires documented undue burden or direct threat.
Pet fees/deposits are not permitted for assistance animals; damage liability is separate.
Some HUD guidance documents (including older notices) may be withdrawn/updated; confirm current HUD guidance before treating any older notice as controlling.

title: Employment access (ADA Title I workplace accommodation)
text: Workplace access is an ADA Title I accommodation workflow, not public-access Q&A. The practical approach is: interactive process meeting, limited documentation when needed, a time-boxed trial with a behavior rubric, and mitigation plans for coworker allergies/phobias. Denial/removal should be tied to undue hardship or direct threat with documentation. Templates beat drama: HR checklist, trial rubric, and balancing worksheet.

claims.text: Allowing a service animal can be a reasonable accommodation handled through the interactive process.
Undue hardship/direct threat are the primary grounds for denial/removal; document decisions.

title: School access (ADA/Section 504; K–12 and higher ed)
text: School access needs an operations plan: staff training, classroom setup, relief breaks, and an incident-response script that matches removal conditions (out of control/not housebroken). K–12 access is grounded in ADA/Section 504 for service animals; higher ed access covers campus spaces, while campus housing additionally implicates FHA accommodation rules (including ESAs in housing-only contexts). Deliverables: SOPs and scripts that reduce conflict while keeping safety front and center.

claims.text: Schools must generally permit service dogs; policies should align to ADA question/removal boundaries.
Campus housing can trigger FHA accommodation for assistance animals (including ESAs) within housing areas.

title: Behavior triage for working-dog pathways
text: A green/yellow/red triage system prevents the classic service-dog failure mode: pushing an anxious dog into public until it explodes. Yellow flags (persistent stress signals, slow recovery, avoidance) mean reduce exposure and rebuild coping skills. Red flags (growl/snap/bite, panic/escape, uncontrolled lunging) mean abort exposure, implement a safety plan (often muzzle/barriers), and refer to qualified professionals. This is a safety and ethics requirement, not a vibe.

claims.text: Aggression or uncontrolled public behavior is incompatible with public-access working standards and should trigger cessation + professional evaluation.

title: Service task taxonomy and claims boundaries
text: Treat tasks like software: define them as observable behaviors with clear criteria, proofing plans, and maintenance schedules. Tasks must be disability-related work (not comfort). A taxonomy lets you reuse training patterns across service and sport. High-risk regions—mobility bracing/counterbalance and medical alert claims—need hard safety boundaries and conservative documentation language that avoids medical promises without validation.

claims.text: Service tasks must be disability-related work/tasks; comfort alone is not sufficient.

title: Public access (ADA) — standards, assessment, and training progression
text: Public access training is built around what ADA actually enforces: the dog must be under control and housebroken, and may be removed if it is out of control and the handler cannot regain effective control, or if it is not housebroken. When a person’s disability or the dog’s task is not obvious, staff in public accommodations are limited to the ADA “two questions” (need because of a disability; what task/work the dog is trained to do) and may not require documentation or demonstrations. ODA treats these legal minimums as hard gates, then translates “under control” into trainer-observable criteria (loose leash, neutral passing, settle, no solicitation, rapid recovery from surprises). Industry rubrics like IAADP’s Minimum Training Standards can be used as a benchmark for training volume and behavioral neutrality, but they are not law.

claims.text: ADA guidance allows a service animal to be removed if it is out of control and the handler cannot or will not take effective action to control it, or if it is not housebroken.
Staff in public accommodations may ask only the ADA “two questions” when the disability/task is not obvious and may not require documentation.
IAADP publishes a public access minimum training standard commonly used as a benchmark for obedience and public behavior neutrality.

title: Public access (ADA) — standards, assessment, and training progression
text: ODA’s internal public-access gate is a pass/fail checklist designed to detect the two ADA failure modes (out of control; not housebroken) early. Core items: (1) loose leash walking with stops/turns, (2) distraction neutrality (dropped food, people, calm dog passing), (3) no unnecessary barking/whining, (4) ability to settle quietly under/near a chair or table for several minutes, (5) timely response to basic handler cues in the environment, and (6) zero toileting accidents in public. Any hard fail ends the test and triggers targeted drills plus regression to a lower-distraction stage. This checklist is an operational translation layer; it should be audited and updated when ADA guidance or widely-used PAT rubrics change.

claims.text: A pass/fail checklist covering loose leash control, neutrality, settle, cue response, and toileting reliability is a practical translation of ADA’s “under control / housebroken” criteria for training QA.
